ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Familiarity with important genes, interactions/pathways, and models of developmental signalling, as well as with the significant model organisms in developmental research.
Overview of developmental processes
I learned a lot about developmental biology
I developed deep insight on the developmental processes and components within multiple organisms.
Developmental biology

This course taught me so much. Primarily, I learned fundamental concepts about cell developmental biology and the machinery that facilitates development. I learned about unity and difference in life. We learned about processes of evolution, genetics, embryology, and more. This was a lovely class.
dev bio

A really deep understanding of concepts crucial to a basic knowledge of developmental biology. The way the course was taught encouraged students to stay on top of the material with weekly quizzes that were low stress (much appreciated!), but also encouraged connection of topics week to week. Between comparing different model organisms or putting together larger pathways between different concepts studied, the insight gained into developmental biology was great.
I learned a lot about the developmental processes and pathways of life. This course gave me a renewed appreciation for the complexity, modularity, and interconnectedness of life.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
A strength of the course was the historical tour through foundational experiments to demonstrate the original questions, observations, and conclusions as a background for why the subjects like Spemann's Organizer are discussed. 

A  weakness of the course the focus/reliance on memorizing a list of signaling molecules. From the student's perspective, it's seldom clear what the significance and function are, especially since many are involved in multiple pathways. This might be helped if there were a reference sheet in the course with an overview of the critical ones to remember.
A lot of the information was so in depth that it seemed impossible to memorize and was extremely unnecessary. The material seemed interesting though.

The content is very interesting. However, the grading of exams is extremely harsh, and it can be unclear what instructors want out of students. It reached the point where I felt that regardless of level of preparation or mastery of the material, I didn't feel confident taking the test. Even if I felt good about all my answers, I never knew how it would be graded. I enjoyed learning about the material very much, but the exams were extremely discouraging.

Strengths: not much day-to-day work besides preparing for weekly quizzes and studying for exams; material was rather interesting

Weaknesses: there was a LOT of memorization in preparation for the exams; not as applicable to human development as I was expecting

Strengths is the depth of the material, you learn a lot about the developmental process. Weaknesses included struggling to understand and dissect the most important concepts from the lectures to know for the exam. There was so much material that it was difficult to condense everything for the exams.

This course has many strengths. Professor Scott Holleys lectures are particularly impactful since they are clear, logical, present information at a measured pace in an understandable way. The course is extremely well taught and that TAs only make the job of learning easier. 

There are few weaknesses I can identify and most of them come from the experience of being a student rather than anything I can say about the course or people. Some lectures were confusing, sometimes I didnt get everything down in my notes, but this isnt really a problem with the course.
it was organized

The strengths were really comprehensive lectures, and the fact that they were recorded. The recordings enabled review of the lectures that were long and very dense in terms of material, so it was very helpful to have. Additionally, the quizzes encouraged students to stay on top of the material in a manageable and relatively low stress way. The biggest weakness was the lack of feedback outside quizzes. I think since COVID meant exams were often administered at varying times, not knowing performance was tough, though the material was relatively exam specific and didn't really impact preparation for the next.

strengths:
Content is very interesting, Scott Holley is an amazing professor and his lectures are engaging
weaknesses:
Exams could be brutal at times, Prof. Kankel is a less engaging professor and because there are no slides for his lectures, that material is very difficult to study for especially if you end up missing a lecture

Strengths: Interesting material 
Weaknesses: Some lectures are very dense and hard to follow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It was a relatively interesting class with a low work load.
only if needed for your major
Yes, if they are taking it purely out of interest in developmental biology. If they are not particularly interested in the material and are looking to fulfill a requirement, I would not recommend it.
Only if this course is required for your major or you are absolutely interested in developmental biology. This was a challenging course.
Only if you are truly interested in developmental biology. This course is extremely memorization-heavy, and thus it can become quite tiring to prepare for exams.

To anyone interested in biology, absolutely! This course really opened my eyes to biology at a deeper level. The studies we do/did, the questions we ask/asked, the logic we use, all in the context of understanding how organisms develop across so many life paths. This is a beautiful course.
yes, if needed

Yes! I think this course is hard because there is a lot of material covered that is very detailed. However, I think it was well organized and so interesting. If you are interested in the biological sciences it is a must take, the material and professors were engaging and all the topics are so relevant to the clinical field. Especially in the age of huge development in biotech, understanding the molecular mechanisms associated with development, as well as the experiments done to find answers that have changed the field, is huge asset to anyone hoping to move on in this field.
Yes, if you need to take this for one of your MCDB cores then I would recommend this class as one of them.
No, the lectures are very hard to follow and extremely time consuming without much gain.
